Column: 1917

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M): Sir, yesterday, we ended the day after the slow and steady speech, probably the slowest and steadiest, by the Chairman of the GPC for the Environment, Dr Teo Ho Pin, who raised some issues concerning efforts on pest control andasked what measures were undertaken and how effective they have been.

Sir, crows, cockroaches and rats multiply when food, water and shelter are easily available, and they can feed on garbage in refuse bags that are placed on the floor and not into bins with a tight cover. And food debris left exposed on the floor and not covered properly are also potential food sources. Hence, the most effective way to curb their population growth is to ensure that our environment is kept clean and hygienic. By handling our waste properly and not littering, we can all play a part to keep these pests under control by denying them a ready source of food. In this way, we can all help stem the potential spread of known and unknown diseases by such pests.

Sir, on measures to control crows and cockroaches, I am happy to report that there has been some steady progress over the years. NEA started crow culling in December 2001. It engages CISCO which has four shooters deployed for shooting every day. On weekends, about 30 members of the Singapore Gun Club join in to help. In the last three years, we have successfully reduced the crow population by about 80%, from an estimated 120,000 down to 22,000, and we expect to reduce the crow population further down to about 10,000 in five years' time. To prevent crows from increasing in numbers again, NEA will continue to cull crows regularly. NEA also checks all its markets and food centres as well as licensed food shops regularly to ensure that there are no rodent or cockroach infestations. Any house

Column: 1918

keeping irregularities that could cause infestations are rectified, and rat poisons and insecticides are used to keep the pests under control.NEA also educates its licensees on proper refuse management and disposal. Licensees will be given demerit points for pest infestations found in their premises. Town councils also fog the refuse chutes in HDB blocks regularly to get rid of cockroaches in the chutes and the surrounding areas.

Going forward, like the point mentioned by Dr Teo yesterday, it is not sufficient nor sustainable for NEA and the other public agencies to tackle the problem alone. Through our on-going Singapore's OK campaign, we will continue to involve the grassroots and the local community to encourage residents and shops to play their part by not littering and ensuring that all food wastes are kept in covered bins. Residents and shop tenants should also ensure that their refuse is properly bagged before throwing it into the refuse chutes or bins. It is only with the joint effort of all parties that we can look forward to a Singapore that is truly pest-free.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Lim Swee Say): Sir, yesterday, Mr Iswaran asked for an update on industry development and corporatisation of incineration plants. I am happy to report to the House that the environment industry in Singapore is progressing well. The industry has grown. Five out of the top 10 global companies are now operating in Singapore. The industry is also becoming more innovative and more capable. They also undertake activities with higher technology contents, for example, the trial of the fuel cell vehicles by DaimlerChrysler and the use of the incineration bottom ash for construction of roads. We will continue to build up the capacity, expertise and experience in the industry through a DBOO (Design, Build, Operate and Own) programme, for areas

Column: 1919

such as desalination, NEWater and incineration of wastes.

Mr Iswaran asked whether corporatisation is still on track. Sir, we have earlier announced that we intended to corporatise 30% of our incineration capacity and privatise 70% of capacity. This will proceed. In fact, we are now reviewing whether the role of the private sector could be further increased. Yesterday, Mr Iswaran highlighted several concerns of the industry - asset heavy, potential demand could be affected by our efforts to promote recycling and so on. These are valid concerns. On the part of the ENV, we will take these into consideration as we formulate the final plan for corporatisation and privatisation. We want to do this carefully and do it right, because we have only one chance to privatise our incineration plants. Once it is privatised, we cannot privatise them for the second time. Therefore, we are going to do it very carefully and take inputs from all angles. At the same time, we will study the experience of other countries.

Sir, Dr Teo Ho Pin asked for a progress update on the 1,000 by 1,000 programme, which is our effort to redesign jobs in the environment sector for Singaporean workers. The Ministry of Manpower and the Workforce Development Agency are certainly doing a lot in the areas of employment and job matching. Other Ministries, including the Ministry of the Environment, are also playing their part to contribute to the effort. As far as the environment industry is concerned, it is an industry with the reputation of offering dirty jobs with lousy pay. But, as mentioned by Dr Teo yesterday, the industry today is going through a very rapid pace of transformation. We are seeing higher technology content, a faster pace of innovation as well as a higher level of mechanisation. What this means is that

Column: 1920

the industry has tremendous potential to offer good jobs at decent pay.

Dr Teo mentioned that in time to come we will need to have more specialists to support the growth of the industry. I fully agree. In fact, the development of a skilled manpower base is critical for the industry to become a more productive industry and one that is more competitive and yet, at the same time, offer our environment workers a better quality of life and standard of living. With that in mind, we set ourselves the challenge of creating 1,000 jobs paying at least $1,000 in September last year. This programme is known as 1,000 by 1,000. This is a 3P collective effort. From the public sector, we have the Ministry of Manpower, the Workforce Development Agency and the NEA. From the private sector, we have Waste Management and Recycling Association of Singapore (WMRAS). On the part of the people sector, the CDCs and town councils are all playing a very active part in this programme. Basically, we are trying to reduce the mismatch between jobs and workers. On the one hand, we would like to redesign the jobs in the industry, so that they can be of higher productivity and offer better pay and yet, at the same time, we have to retrain the workers, so that they are better skilled and can take on these jobs. I am happy to say that the collective effort on job redesign is progressing well in terms of mechanisation of the waste collection function and conservancy cleaning. There is a town council project chaired by Mr Ang Mong Seng, together with various town councillors, to look into how we can make the jobs in conservancy cleaning more attractive and, in the process, encourage more locals to take on these jobs.

On the part of skills upgrading for workers, we have so far implemented 19 skills standards under the National Skills

Column: 1921

Recognition System. So far, more than 600 workers have been trained. For hawker centre cleaning, over time, the cleaning contractors would have to make sure that more than 50% of their workers are NSRS-certified within four months of taking on the contract. In the case of waste collection, our long-term target is to aim for 100% NSRS certification.

Dr Teo asked for the progress of the 1,000 by 1,000. Sir, progress has been promising since the launch in October last year. So far, we have been able to match 307 jobs to the retrenched workers, with each being paid more than $1,000. We hope that more can be done in the future. We hope that in time to come we can go beyond 1,000 for 1,000. We look at 1,000 by 1,000 as the first step because, if we can succeed in redesigning 1,000 jobs paying at least $1,000, that would lay the foundation for us to take the second step, which is 1,200 for 1,200, ie, redesign 1,200 jobs paying at least $1,200 per month. When we have reached that, we would be ready to go on to the third step, ie, 1,500 by 1,500, then 2,000 by 2,000. In time to come, we hope that the environment sector will indeed be transformed into a sector that offers jobs that are more productive, equipped with better tools and, at the same time, can be a source of employment for more Singaporeans.

Sir, Dr Teo asked about the progress of the ASEAN Sustainable Cities programme. It is progressing quite well. Since the launch of the ASEAN Sustainable Cities programme, Singapore has been appointed by our ASEAN member countries to coordinate this programme. The programme has attracted not only interest within ASEAN, our ASEAN+3 partners - China, Japan and Korea - have also expressed interest. Last year, when we were at the ASEM meeting, our European counterparts

Column: 1922

likewise expressed interest. In other words, this ASEAN Sustainable Cities programme has the potential of not only promoting best practices within ASEAN and within Asia, it can in fact be a platform to facilitate the sharing of best practices across Asia and Europe as well.

Sir, I now move on to the Singapore's OK campaign. Yesterday, Mdm Cynthia Phua asked whether Singapore is more OK. The Singapore's OK programme was launched in May last year to enhance the cleanliness and hygiene standards in Singapore, not through fines or enforcement, but through community leadership and personal ownership. In the last seven months, 6,200 grassroots leaders and volunteers under the People's Association have staged 1,200 activities to reach out to more than one million people. Today, the hostels, pre-schools and food courts are 100% OK. Even in the case of the construction sites, condominiums and restaurants, they are now more than 90% OK.

Mr Ang Mong Seng asked, how about public toilets? I am happy to say that even our public toilets have improved tremendously. As of today, 92% of our public toilets are OK.

Sir, we are happy that Singapore is indeed more OK. According to the regional offices of the NEA, they observed fewer people spitting on the roads and, at the same time, some of our more litter-prone areas are seeing less litter now. eg, Hougang Mall, Holland Village and Clementi Town Centre. These are indeed very encouraging signs.

Yesterday, Mdm Cynthia Phua also asked what plans we have to bring the Singapore's OK campaign to a higher plane of achievement. This is a very important point, because we must always remind ourselves that no country is virus-proof, and Singapore is no exception. This is because the threat can come from

Column: 1923

known and unknown viruses, from new and mutated viruses. We do not know when they will strike. We also do not know how they will spread. But one thing we do know is that if we can keep our living environment cleaner and more hygienic, we will make it more difficult for viruses to grow and for infectious diseases to spread. In other words, even though we cannot be virus-proof, we can do our best to become more virus-resistant.

Some Members may ask what is the difference between virus-proof and virus-resistant. Sir, when I was young, my first watch, given by my father, was a very nice Seiko watch. I was very happy as it was the first time I had a watch on my wrist. So everywhere I went, I made sure that the watch was on my wrist. One day, I went to the Farrer Park public swimming pool to swim. When I was young, I was not a good swimmer. There were a big pool and a shallow pool. The shallow pool was about one metre deep so it was quite safe. I went to the shallow pool and because I liked my watch so much, I left it on. After swimming for a while in this shallow pool, I found, to my horror, that water actually seeped into the watch. I was very upset. I went to the shop dealer and demanded for an explanation. The shop owner looked at me and asked, "What has happened to your watch?" I said, "I went swimming at Farrer Park yesterday with my watch on." He said, "No, you are not supposed to swim with your watch on." But I said, "This watch is water-resistant." He said, "Yeh, it is water-resistant but it is not water-proof." He said that if the watch is water-proof we can wear the watch for swimming and diving. But for water-resistant, it is only resistant against raindrops but not in a swimming pool.

Likewise, in our battle against virus, no country can claim to be virus-proof.

Column: 1924

No country can say, "Look, no virus can attack this country." As I have mentioned, there will be new and mutated viruses. But every country obviously wants to do its best to be as virus-resistant as possible so that hopefully, we will be able to reduce and minimise the outbreak of viruses and infectious diseases.

Therefore, it is important, as Mdm Cynthia Phua mentioned, that we must press on with Singapore's OK to strive for 100% for all our public places. In the coming years, we aim to increase our attention in four areas. These are our four priority areas.

The first priority area is the hawker centres and wet markets because they are one of our weak links today. Today, 15% of the food centres and 37% of markets in Singapore are still not OK due to poor housekeeping. What NEA, together with Town Councils, will be doing is to improve the housekeeping standards and, at the same time, increase the frequency of major washing. Instead of once or twice a year, we intend to increase it to three times a year. Hopefully, in time to come, many of our hawker centres and wet markets will be OK too.

Sir, there is another reason why we should do our best to make sure that our hawker centres are OK. Recently, my new Permanent Secretary, BG Tan Yong Soon, told me very excitedly,"Minister, you know, there is something great about hawker centres." I asked, "What is so great about our hawker centres?" He said, "Our hawker centres are now in the same class as the Lake District in England, the North Pole in Norway, the Pyramids in Egypt, the Great Wall of China, Taj Mahal of India and the Grand Canyon of USA." I asked, "Are you all right or not? What are you talking about?" He shared with me this book which just came out in the market. It is entitled, "One thousand places to see before you die". All the places that I have mentioned

Column: 1925

are in this book. When we turn to the pages on Singapore, there are two places in Singapore which everybody in this world should see before they die. One is the Raffles Hotel and the other is Singapore's hawker centres.

Sir, the food we have in the hawker centres today is not just our way of life but it is a unique way of Singapore's life. I think the Singapore Tourism Board, in an effort to promote "Uniquely Singapore" will pay attention to our hawker centres too.

Mr Zainul Abidin asked for the progress of our Hawkers Upgrading Programme (HUP). I am happy that the programme is progressing well. So far, 59, out of 113 hawker centres have either been upgraded or under development or earmarked to be upgraded. Mr Zainul also asked whether it is the intention to centralise the management of all the hawker centres including HDB hawker centres under one agency. The answer is yes. Starting from 1st April, the management of the 92 HDB hawker centres will come under NEA as well.

Mr Ang Mong Seng asked whether, after the centralisation and consolidation, the NEA can take over the functions from the town councils. The answer is no, because most of the HDB hawker centres are located in our HDB estates and it is not the NEA's intention to reduce the community ownership and links in these hawker centres. So the role of the town councils will not change.

Sir, Mr Ang Mong Seng and Mr Wee Siew Kim also asked whether we will build new wet markets and hawker centres. There is no plan to do so. In our newer housing estates today, the private sector is basically the one to gauge the demand and from there, they set up

Column: 1926

coffee shops, air-conditioned food courts and supermarkets to meet the demand of the community. This will continue. What the Government will do is to continue to zone sites for commercial development and to allow the private operators to meet this demand by setting up appropriate types of eating and marketing facilities. But as far as the older estates are concerned, the Government-operated hawker centres will continue to be upgraded so that the private sector-operated coffee shops and food courts, and the Government-owned hawker centres and wet markets can co-exist and compete in a healthy manner.

Sir, during the MTI's Committee of Supply, Mr Wee Siew Kim asked whether ENV has any intention to bring back mobile hawkers. Let me explain here that our main concern is public health, especially for the sale of cooked food. Thirty years ago, in 1974, ENV stopped issuing licences for mobile hawkers for the sale of food, ice-cream, bread, and so on. Ten years ago, in 1994, ENV conducted an island-wide registration of all stationary street hawkers and vendors, like cobblers, newspaper vendors, and so on. They are granted non-transferable permits that are subjected to annual renewal. In some cases, due to road safety considerations, they were also re-sited.

Since 1996, ENV stopped issuing any new licence. However, in 2000, in response to various appeals by Members of Parliament, grassroots leaders and others, ENV started to allow some of these itinerant ice-cream vendors to operate in the town council area, with the support of the town councils. I am happy to say that to-date, over the last 3-4 years, we have issued 260 permits for them to sell ice-cream within the town council area. Last night, I saw one of them, Mdm Lin Huji on TV News. She is operating in Marine Parade. I looked at the stall she is operating. It is very well

Column: 1927

designed. When she was handling the ice-cream, she was wearing gloves. All the paper waste is properly collected. That is the way to go. Through their own efforts, they are able to earn a living while, at the same time, taking care of the environment.

However, Sir, I want to say that every year, ENV also receives many complaints regarding illegal hawking. In fact, every year, more than 3,000 of them come from shopkeepers and members of the public. This is due to unfair competition posed by the street hawkers to the shops. Therefore, on the one hand, ENV is receptive to the idea of increasing the number of licences for the mobile hawkers but, at the same time, we have to make sure that the situation does not get out of control, whether it is from the viewpoint of public health or from the standpoint of obstruction to pedestrians, or unfair competition to the shopkeepers.

What we will do is to take it one step at a time, gradually. We have to make sure that we allow the situation to evolve. What NEA intends to do now is to extend the arrangement that we have with town councils to the other public places, such as parks, car parks and pedestrian malls. We would also like to extend the list of items, maybe from ice-cream to other items which are not easily perishable and unlikely to cause public health problems. For example, these could include pre-packed snacks, candies, biscuits, canned drinks and even kacang putih. Along this line, last month, ENV met with NParks, LTA, URA and HDB and they are now working out the guidelines and details. Depending on the response from the public, we may also have to put in place a system for allocation.

Mr Ang Mong Seng asked whether we will do more to encourage more public toilets to be OK. The answer is yes. In fact, public toilets are the second area of our priorities in the coming years. So far,

Column: 1928

out of the 29,000 public toilets, 26,600 are already OK, about 92%. We will continue to reach out to the remaining 8% to push for 100% OK. At the same time, the upgrading of public toilets at coffee shops is also progressing well. As of now, about 350 coffee shops have upgraded their public toilets – about one out of every four. We have just extended this programme by one more year and, hopefully, more will take part.

Sir, let me move on to the third area, which is the point brought up by Dr Teo Ho Pin regarding pest control measures and what more can be done to engage all the stakeholders. Sir, our war against the rodents will be the third area of priority in the coming years. Our target is to bring down the number of burrows per precinct to less than five. That is our target. As of today, out of the 16 town council estates, only three town council estates are able to meet this target. For the rest, we have about six to 41 burrows per precinct. So there is still a lot of work to be done. We believe that this can be done. We can succeed in reducing the number of burrows per precinct because, over the last couple of years, we have been focusing on the hotspot areas and we are achieving fairly good results. For example, if we were to go to Holland Village, we used to have 32 burrows in that area, but it is now down to eight; Chinatown, from 45, now down to six; Geylang Serai, from 28, down to one. Our challenge is to spread this success to the other areas as well.

The key reasons why we have succeeded in some of these hotspot areas are, firstly, there were regular checks by the town councils, pest control companies and NEA. Secondly, we have good housekeeping by the shopkeepers. Thirdly, there was proper handling of food waste by the waste collectors and the cleaners. And lastly, there is no littering or leaving behind of food for strays by members of the public. What we have to

Column: 1929

do is to continue in this effort. I am happy to say that we have decided to launch a new initiative under the Singapore's OK, to be known as "Rat Attack". This "Rat Attack" will start with a pilot in five town councils – one each in each of the CDC districts. This "Rat Attack" will be conducted under joint ownership of the pest control companies, grassroots organisations, shopkeepers, food shop operators, public waste collectors, hawkers and the market stallholders.

NEA will co-fund this "Rat Attack" exercise with the town councils, using the 3P Partnership Fund of NEA which I mentioned yesterday. This is an eight-month programme, starting this month. It will go through four months of intensive control, followed by another four months of maintenance. From there, we will then assess the effectiveness of this programme before we roll out to the other areas.

Sir, let me come to the fourth area of priority in the coming year, which is to address the dengue situation in Singapore. As I have mentioned, the dengue outbreak in the region started two years ago. However, I am happy to say that the situation in Singapore has shown signs of improvement. For example, in the first 10 weeks of this year, on the average, we have 68 cases per week, compared to 85 per week the same time last year. In the last four weeks, the average number has continued to drop to 61 per week.

Sir, some Members asked yesterday whether it is possible to stop the importation of dengue cases from our region. The answer is no. Why? Because 90% of the people bitten by Aedes mosquitoes and infected with dengue viruses do not show any symptom. In other words, not everybody who is infected by the dengue virus will

Column: 1930

come down with the dengue symptoms. 90% have no symptom. Therefore, it is very difficult to detect who are the ones who actually carry the virus in their bodies. What we can do is to continue to step up surveillance, to identify hotspots and to intensify our inspections. Last year, NEA inspected more than 300,000 premises. In February 2004 alone, they inspected more than 19,000 premises. Sir, the encouraging sign is that breeding grounds are beginning to decrease in some of the places. For example, in our schools, in 1999, on the average, one out of seven schools was found to breed mosquitoes. Today, it has come down to 5%, or one in 20. Of course, we will continue to bring it down. Construction sites have dropped by half in terms of the frequency of mosquito breeding, from 13% in 1999 to less than 7% now. What is even more encouraging, Sir, is that we are seeing more active participation by the community. For example, even our school children are now getting involved through the programme known as the Mossie Buster. I was very happy to see that in the latest issue of the Thumbs Up there is a big write-up on how our kids are now helping to fight this war against dengue. If we look at their faces, they were really keen and interested in what they were doing. This is the kind of effort we should do more and more in our community.

Sir, what is the next thing we should do? Our next target in our war against dengue is to target our homes. Why do I say so? Over the years, we were surprised to find that the percentage of households breeding mosquitoes has been on the increase. The Government subsidies are aimed at making childcare an affordable necessity to families. However, the current childcare subsidy of up to $150 per month for working mothers has been in effect since 1995 and has not changed since then.

The main cost of operating childcare centre is manpower. I am sure, Sir, wages go up every year. As childcare costs and fees increase, Government subsidies

Column: 1994

should also increase in order for Government to continue to provide a similar level of financial support to parents. As the average monthly fee for full-day childcare services is about $550, I propose that the subsidy be increased to $250 per month to make it more affordable for parents.

Sir, how to care for infants is a key concern for working parents. Infant care provided at childcare centres is currently not accessible to many parents. Out of 650 childcare centres in Singapore, only 24 of them provide infant care services. This number should be increased.

The cost of providing care for infants is about five times that for older children. I would like to appeal to the Minister to increase the subsidy for infants. I understand that it costs the childcare centre about $900 per month per infant. So, I would like to appeal to the Minister to increase the subsidy to about $400-$500 per month for the infant child.

I am glad that MCDS has put in place the Family Day Care Services, which is an affordable home-based infant care service by trained caregivers for infants and toddlers aged two to 18 months. It extends the spectrum of care services to meet the varied childcare needs of families. The fees for Family Day Care Services range from about $500 to $625 per month. I would like to ask the Minister whether MCDS would also consider giving subsidies to parents who use the home-based nanny programme.

     Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): Sir, childcare concerns are a top worry for many couples. Working parents need more support in childcare arrangements. There are less than 24 childcare facilities that offer infant care for babies younger than 18 months. May I ask the Minister on the progress of such childcare centres? Could the Minister encourage more efforts in setting up such centres to expedite their

Column: 1995

availability to working mothers who cannot find other alternatives in childcare? Could the Minister also pay heed to the psychological aspect of such young children in these centres, such as the necessity for a constant mother-figure to prevent distressed children and other developmental problems and for periodic checks by child psychologists?

Presently, fees at such centres are about $700 to $1,200 per month. These fees are beyond the affordability of many working parents. In view of our declining TFR, we should try to improve on childcare facilities, making them conveniently available and subsidising fees at 75%.

The ideal caregivers for infants are, of course, the parents themselves. However, in the context of Singapore, immediate family members, relatives, neighbours and even friends can be reasonably good parent-substitutes. Therefore, childcare incentives should also be extended to grandparents, nannies and relatives who are supervised and certified by MCDS. This will give working couples the choice of homecare for their children and will provide the elderly or housewives with some income while they stay home.

Better childcare centres staffed with certified professionals and dedicated caregivers will give peace of mind to parents who now want professional care for their children. There should be more childcare centres conveniently located in relation to either the home or the workplace. This, in effect, calls for employers to consider providing childcare centres at the workplace. In this respect, I hope more generous grants can be given to companies to set up childcare centres at workplaces. The present $26,000 is too small an amount for set-up costs, especially for those providing childcare centres in accordance with MCDS guidelines.

Column: 1996

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Sir, the Government's recent announcement that it will add another 3,000 infant care places in the next five years, representing a 10-fold increase over the present number of places available, as well as initiatives like the home-based nanny matching services, are indeed welcomed. Presumably to accommodate the additional places, the number of infant care centres will also be increased. I would like to urge the Ministry to not only look into the setting up of infant care centres in residential areas but also encourage the setting up of child and infant care centres in areas with high concentration of workers, such as in the CBD, business parks and non-pollutive light industrial areas. This would make these centres more accessible to working mothers and, as gender roles harmonise even further, fathers as well could also visit their children over their lunch breaks.

MCDS could work with MND to give developers and building owners incentives to set aside space for such use, for instance, by excluding such space from the gross floor area computation up to a pre-determined amount. Further, the subsidy, particularly for infant care, should be raised as the cost of infant care can be up to $1,000 or even more per infant.

Also, I would like to urge the Minister to aggressively promote the home-based nanny matching service which appears to have been very well received. This benefits both the parents as well as the nannies. The scheme could be administered jointly by MCDS and grassroots organisations whose members have personal knowledge of their families in any particular precinct. However, I would like to ask that the prospective caregivers be interviewed, their homes be inspected, and it be made compulsory for all potential caregivers to attend a properly conducted course on infant and childcare to ensure that they are well

Column: 1997

qualified for the task. As an additional step, some kind of registry of nannies should be kept by, say, the CDCs and any misdemeanour reported would count against the registration. This would also help to give assurance to parents who entrust their infants to these nannies.

Currently, many childcare centres only open till 6.00 pm. I would like to ask the Minister to encourage more centres to open till later as many parents have to rush home from work to fetch their children. Additional subsidy could, for instance, be given to child/infant care centres that extend their operating hours.

     Mr Gan Kim Yong: Sir, in line with our efforts to help couples cope with the difficulties in raising children, we should improve our infant and childcare system, so that they can benefit from it. In this regard, I would like to make three proposals.

Firstly, in terms of cost and subsidy. Today, the costs of such services are very high. The subsidy of up to $150 a month is helpful but may not be enough. This is also low compared with Government’s subsidy of $300 per month for students in the primary school. In fact, for childcare and infant care centres, the operating costs are higher because of the lower teacher to student ratio. Although lower income families can apply for centre-based financial assistance schemes, the income ceiling of $1,500 is also too low, especially if the family has more than two children. Perhaps a per capita income ceiling would be more equitable.

Secondly, in terms of convenience, some parents prefer childcare centres nearer to their workplace of work so that they can reach their children easily and quickly when an emergency arises, and they can also visit them during lunch breaks. We should perhaps consciously

Column: 1998

promote childcare centres at industrial and commercial centres. We should encourage larger companies to join hands and operate their own childcare services. Some incentives could also be provided to them.

Thirdly, informal care services. Some parents would prefer to seek help from their relatives to look after their babies. In fact, grandparents play a crucial role in providing childcare and encouraging our young people to have children. We should therefore consider extending the childcare subsidy to such cases, perhaps with some safeguards to prevent abuse and maybe with a lower amount, since the cost of homecare is likely to be lower than professionally run childcare centres.

Sir, I hope the Minister can consider these three suggestions.

     Mr Andy Gan Lai Chiang (Marine Parade): Sir, I would like to speak on the proliferation of childcare centres in private residential areas.

Providing childcare centres is now a necessity and a priority as the Government explores ways to encourage procreation. As more calls are made to provide infant care and childcare centres, it is timely that we assess the location of childcare centres in private residential areas. Existing MCDS guidelines state that "permanent permission is granted to service providers of childcare centres, student care centres and kindergartens meeting the requirements of MCDS and MOE to operate in civic and community institutional buildings, educational institutions, commercial buildings, HDB void decks and non-landed residential developments. Temporary permission is granted for such centres to operate from landed housing estates, including semi-detached houses and corner terrace houses."

Column: 1999

Locating childcare centres in private residential landed property should not be encouraged for long-term use. There is a real need to have appropriate guidelines established to ensure that childcare centres complement the existing environment and do not adversely affect the peace and quiet of the private estates. Within private landed properties in Mountbatten alone, there are about 20 childcare centres, some of which are located close to each other. While I support the need for more childcare centres, and I am ready to work with MCDS to find suitable alternate sites for these centres, urban planners and approval authorities should keep in mind residents' needs on how such a proliferation of childcare centres would affect the residential landscape. Guidelines requiring neighhours' support should be made. And I find that most residents in private estates are supportive once such guidelines are known and the centre operators observe them.

Service providers should be made to provide for adequate vehicular drop-off and pick-up points, smooth traffic flows for the residents and pay attention to general road safety requirements. Even as we relish having more of such services, we should refrain from compromising the standards of proper urban planning and the privacy of private residential owners.

     Before and After School Care

Mdm Halimah Yacob:Sir, I wish to raise two issues pertaining to the before-and-after-school care services. The first one is the lack of before-and-after-school care facilities to cater to the needs of working parents with primary school going children. The other issue which parents have raised is insufficient funding for such services which makes it costly for parents to put their children in the before-and-after-school care services.

Column: 2000

1.45 pm

Sir, currently, MCDS only subsidises before-and-after-school care services run by VWOs and for low income families. However, the subsidy does not apply to non-VWO-run centres and the fees can be quite costly for parents. This is quite limited and restrictive, considering that there are only a few VWOs operating before-and-after-school care centres.

Sir, we do not want to see more latch-key children left to their own devices, watching TV programmes the whole day or, worse still, undesirable VCDs, or falling into bad company. Before-and-after-school care services, if properly run, serve an important need by filling thevoid with meaningful activities for primary school children when parents are not around. Hence, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether he will consider extending the subsidy to commercial before-and-after-school care centres as well so that more parents can have access to them. Secondly, what more can be done to help expand the establishment of more before-and-after-school care services?

     Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, I would like to thank Members who have spoken on the issue of procreation and balancing worklife. Sir, as you know, DPM Lee has stated in the Budget Statement that many of the suggestions on marriage and procreation, which Members have raised last week, will be referred to the Working Committee on Population for consideration. I thought I should share with Members the background work that my Ministry has been doing in the past one year.

Sir, my Ministry has spearheaded two study trips to five countries. We have also obtained the views of more than 10,000 people through two national surveys, 10 focus group discussions, and various topics posted on the Feedback Unit's

Column: 2001

Consultation Portal. In addition, we have received more than 300 phone calls and 1,200 emails from members of the public. I would like to thank all of them for their kind contribution and the time they spent on a very important issue.

Let me share some of our key findings. From our survey of 3,000 married persons on the underlying motivations for marriage and procreation, nearly four out of five felt that the three-child family norm was "just nice". However, at the individual level, the overall intended and actual family size was two children, on average, largely because of constraints. These were lack of time and energy for children, as well as concerns about financial support. This means that families can and should be helped to achieve the ideal family size they desire. Financial measures alone might not work,but they should remain as part of our package of measures.

Sir, may I just alert Members to the handouts that I have given to them on the various findings that were made on the study trips. I would like now to share withMembers onsome of the findings.

Sir, handout 1 is on female labour force and TFR for 1975 and 2001. Mdm Halimah Yacob would be interested to know that from our study trips, we learnt that some developed countries with very high rates of female employment now also have high birth rates. This was not the case some 30 years ago when high female employment correlated with low birth rates.

Sir, this is indeed encouraging. If you look at handout 2, it shows that labour market and social adjustments can take place to address work-life concerns. The result is that women can both have career and family, and need not choose. However, different countries achieve the

Column: 2002

balance in different ways. In the Netherlands, about 60% of females and 15% of males work part-time. As opposed to the dual income or single breadwinner model, the one-and-a-half income model is fairly popular there, despite the costs of living there. Young couples are also moving towards the "combination scenario" of three-quarters work and incomes for both mothers and fathers.

Sir, on the other hand, if you look out at handout3, Norway, France and Sweden provide strong childcare support to parents who work full-time. Furthermore, in all three countries, for parents who prefer more time with their children, they have both part-time and flexi-time schemes. Thus, a variety of options are available for couples to choose how they wish to achieve their work-life balance.

Sir, in terms of maternity leave, and this is handout4, Netherlands has 16 weeks of paid leave while France also has the same length of leave for the first two children, but this shoots up to 26 weeks for the third. Both Norway and Sweden have wage-compensated, job-protected parental leave which can be for up to 18 months or so, of which specific periods are separately reserved for the women and men. These leave schemes allow mothers and fathers to enjoy their children and family life.

Now, if I ask you to turn your attention to handout5, this is where the reality begins to sink in. These generous measures come with a hefty price tag. Norway and Sweden spend about 3.5% of their GDP on family-related benefits. In both these countries as well as the Netherlands and France, income tax rates are high going up to 40%-50%, and the value added tax (which is equivalent to our GST) is double-digit, and there are also social security contributions. Our philosophy here has been different. We

Column: 2003

prefer to leave more disposable income with the citizens so they can choose how they wish to spend it on what they need.

In Singapore, like in these other developed countries, women, especially those who have undergone years of education, want to work. While we do not want to go towards an expensive family support system, and must take into account business concerns, we still need to do more. If we do not help our women, they will have to choose between a mummy or career track. And this is a lose-lose situation, as Singapore will then end up with fewer mothers and babies, as well as a smaller workforce.

Sir, the idea of having children is important to every society. The United Nationsdid a study a couple of years ago to identify what were the factors responsible for the growth of some of the countries in the NIEs. And they discovered that when you havea highratio of young people to older people and, with the right policies of education, healthcare and development programmes, the country will grow. They have termed this opportunity or this trend the demographic bonus. By all accounts, we are now experiencing our demographic bonus. It would appear that this bonus is only a one-time thing. So in view of this trend, I think there is a concern from all of us to reflect on how best we can try and help out to prop up the TFR for Singapore.

Having or not having enough children in the next generation affects everyone. Its impact reverberates across society, whether we are married or single, male or female. Children rejuvenate society; and we all need them.

Sir, let me now turn to the issues raised by various Members on work-life strategies. Mdm Halimah and Mr Yeo Guat Kwang have stressed the importance of work-life strategies to enable individuals to balance work and family

Column: 2004

responsibilities. I fully agree with them. I also agree with Ms Braema that every person, male or female, single or married, has multiple roles and responsibilities at work and at home. Indeed, singles are members of the family and have legitimate work-life concerns as well. Work-life harmony concerns all of us and is not just the exclusive prerogative of parents or married persons.

Sir, my Ministry has proactively addressed the need to balance work and life by setting up the Work-Life Unit three years ago, under your leadership then, Sir. The Unit helps employers implement work-life strategies that align their business goals with their employees' personal and family needs, which apply to married people as well as singles. The most common and useful practices in the workplace are naturally those that address the main concerns of employees. Work-life practices can be broadly classified into flexible work arrangements, leave benefits and employee support schemes. Flexible work arrangements include flexi-time, part-time work and a compressed work week. Examples of leave benefits are family care leave and parental leave while employee support schemes cover health and wellness programmes and social activities.

Sir, our approach to this issue is a three-pronged one. We promote work-life strategy, we build local capability and we facilitate funding for consultancy and training. We have taken the "tripartite approach" of Government, employers and unions working hand in hand. Our partners are the Ministry of Manpower, SNEF and NTUC. Together, we adopt a holistic concept of work-life harmony based on the 'whole person'. We also partner business associations, training agencies, Health Promotion Board, SPRING Singapore, voluntary welfare organisations and other Government and statutory bodies to organise promotional and training events. So far, we have

Column: 2005

organised more than 140 such events that have reached about 10,000 CEOs and HR practitioners.

Sir, in response to feedback from employers, we have produced resource materials to guide employers on how to implement work-life programmes. We have trained a pool of about 20 work-life consultants to assist companies implement work-life programmes. In addition, the Work-life Unit has obtained SPRING Singapore's agreement to extend the Local Enterprise Technical Assistance Scheme (LETAS) grant to SMEs wishing to engage work-life consultants. All organisations can also tap on the enhanced Skills Development Fund to send their staff for work-life training.

Sir, recently my Ministry commissioned a bottom-line study on the impact of work-life programmes on 11 local family friendly organisations. The findings show that these programmes reaped positive returns from implementing work-life programmes. Our tripartite partners have also developed a set of guidelines on Best Work-Life Practices. Mooted by Mdm Halimah Yacob herself, the guidelines will serve as a roadmap for organisations to adopt work-life strategies. MCDS will be releasing the detailed findings of this study and the guidelines soon.

Although we may be in the infant stage of promoting work-life compared to countries like the US and Australia who are 20 years ahead of us, our efforts have shown results. Many organisations are now showing interest in work-life and recognise the benefits of being family friendly. This is evident from the increasing response to the upcoming Singapore Family-Friendly Employer Award – a biennial award that recognises family-friendly organisations. A total of 456 organisations applied for the Award

Column: 2006

this year as compared to 342 in 2000. There was also a quantum leap in the number of organisations which meet the shortlisting criteria. The number vying for this biennial Award has increased from 16 in year 2000 to 110 this year.

The past winners of the Award have formed the Employer Alliance on Work and Family, chaired by Dr Jennifer Lee. Being convinced of the importance of work-life balance and the long-term business case, the Alliance has been sharing the companies' experiences and the benefits they reaped from being family friendly.

Sir, we have just placed Singapore on the international work-life map despite the fact that we only started this programme three years ago. The Head of the Work-Life Unit was recently invited to a work-life conference organised by the Alliance for Work-Life Progress held in the United States. The presentation was well received and many international work-life experts applauded our efforts and our tripartite approach as €˜innovative' and holistic.

Sir, adopting a work-life friendly culture requires a paradigm shift in the mindset of both the employers and employees. It has to be based on the principle of reciprocity. Employees must be responsive, responsible, adaptable and accountable in the usage of work-life programmes. After all, at the end of the day they have a job to perform! The challenge lies in helping both single and married individuals shape their own work-life harmony by setting realistic life and career goals. My Ministry will focus on helping the individual achieve personal work-life effectiveness through providing resource materials as well as sharing success work-life stories.

Let me just share with the House one example of how work-life arrangements have benefited our women. MsKaren

Column: 2007

Phua, previously worked part time and job shared in MINDEF. Her previous job at MINDEF allowed her to job share. She worked from Monday to Wednesday and her colleagues worked other days. The Mil-Com CEO, Dr Diana Young, readily agreed to her proposal for the same flexible work arrangement. Now a HR and training manager at Mil-Com, she said that she was blessed to have had supportive employers that allow her to work three days a week. This allows her to spend more time with her two primary school children and back to working full time now as the children are older. So it provides an opportunity for her to transit and change her lifestyle while the kids are young and when the kids are older, she can go back to full time work.

Sir, let me now move on to the issue of childcare and infant care. Many Members have spoken on this issue and I really thank them as this is a very important issue. Strong childcare infrastructure, as pointed out by many Members, is certainly another critical factor, and this is important if we are to help our families to have more children. As at end February 2004, there are more than 650 centres providing almost 55,000 places. MCDS is working towards a target of providing 58,000 childcare places by FY 2005. This will meet the needs of 25% of children below seven years of age. Nevertheless, we take into account the enrolment at existing centres, and review this target annually to ensure that there is no over-supply. While many of these centres would be in HDB void decks, some would be in residential landed estates. Let me assure Mr Andy Gan that we will continue to work closely with the URA and childcare operators to minimise inconveniences to other residents.

Several Members have also spoken about the need for us to work with employers to provide childcare centres at workplaces.I would like to report that

Column: 2008

we already have many places which are available, both at Government agencies and non-Government agencies. A good example would be Creative Technology in Jurong, where they have an inhouse childcare centre. We will work with every employer who is prepared to open up childcare centres in their workplaces, and see how best we can facilitate that. I understand Dr Lily Neo's concern about the subsidy level of $26,000, but we have to be mindful that we do not want childcare centres to proliferate. As it is now, there is already some excess capacity in our childcare centres. So, we will continue to work with employers on how best we can open up childcare centres at workplaces, because that is a very good move. My own Ministry has a childcare centre that has benefited a lot of my staff who have young children.

Sir, let me now move on to infant care. Singapore, like Italy, does not yet have good infrastructure for infant care. Less than 1% of our infants here are enrolled in infant care centres. Given the much higher staff-child ratios required of infant care centres, we must consider implementing an infant care subsidy rate that is different and higher than the current childcare subsidy. But I assure the Member that the matter is part of the holistic review of marriage and procreation measures which will be completed by August this year.

My Ministry values our partnership with childcare operators, and my officers meet them regularly to review and improve our procedures. The procedures for setting up childcare or infant care centres are clearly set out on our website, www.childcarelink.gov.sg. My officers also actively provide consultation to interested operators to enable them to meet licensing requirements which ensure proper standards of care. If Members or potential operators have specific feedback or suggestions on how to improve the process, my officers would be happy to

Column: 2009

discuss the matter with them. We encourage more operators to provide infant care services, either in their current childcare centres or through setting up new centres. We will continue to offer capital grants to VWOs to defray the start-up costs. As mentioned earlier, capital grants are also extended to employers, if they set up workplace centres. These measures will help to keep fees affordable. But we are mindful that the infant care industry must be financially self-sustainable. It is a new industry.

Sir, at the same time, parents can also use the Baby Bonus scheme to pay for the cost of centre-based care. As at February this year, $104.5 million has been paid out in Baby Bonus. The Government has also paid out $27.9 million under the Third Child Paid Maternity Leave scheme, of which $1.6 million was paid to self-employed mothers. Ultimately, it is not more subsidies or financial support that would keep prices down, but more competition from having more centre places.

Apart from affordability, let me assure Members that my Ministry will also ensure quality, through both the Child Care Centres' Act and Regulations and through licensing. We focus on dimensions, such as safety, hygiene, nutrition, programme and curriculum and, of course, staff and training. I am proud to say that, today, over 90% of childcare centre supervisors and teachers have either been trained or are undergoing training at the required level. In addition, MCDS has developed a dedicated training programme for infant care personnel in consultation with childcare experts, healthcare professionals from the Ministry of Health, KK Women's and Children's Hospital, and the Ministry of the Environment.

Sir, to provide more options to parents, we announced in January this

Column: 2010

year a new home-based care option for infants, known as Family Day Care. Childcare centres will match interested parents with trained caregivers who will care for the infants in a home. I am happy to say that even before the service was fully operational on 1st March this year, close to 1,000 parents and caregivers had indicated interest. Of these, 230 parents and 270 caregivers have registered for the service.

Sir, Dr Amy Khor has suggested that we should be aggressive in pushing this scheme. I support her. At the same time, we have to allow the industry to develop because, as she rightly pointed out, we have to have the right people to become nannies and babysitters. On her suggestion as to whether or not we could administer this together with MCDS and a grassroots organisation, at the moment, the scheme is being handled by the CDCs together with the Family Service Centres. Let us evolve, as we are dealing with young children and the level of expertise that is needed to manage such a scheme, which the Member must agree with me, should be very high, especially given the fact they are young and their needs may be different from toddlers and other children.

She also suggested a registry of nannies to be placed at the CDCs. I think that is a good idea. I will put it up to the five Mayors as to whether or not they may consider that. Dr Amy Khor has also suggested that we should open more childcare centres later to allow parents who work late to come back. As it is now, there are some centres which have done so, in consultation with the parents. Some of them do keep their lights open up to 7.00 pm to allow parents who are working late to come back. But this is something that is mutually agreed between the parents and the childcare operators.

Sir, I think I have addressed most of the concerns on childcare. The last point

Column: 2011

is about accessibility, in terms of childcare centres in workplaces. DrAmy Khor suggests that wecollaborate with MND on the gross floor space. Sir, I am notquite familiar with that. But let us look into how we can help more employers who are prepared to open up childcare centres at their workplaces.I agree with her and Dr Lily Neo and others that having childcare centres near the workplace will help parents, both fathers and mothers, to have peace of mind to know that their child is being taken care of professionally and being well taken care of.

Sir, finally, I would now like to address Mdm Halimah's query on before-and-after-school care, which is also known as student care. As pointed out by her, this service is provided by both commercial and VWO operators, and has grown to be fairly popular among parents as an alternative care arrangement for their older children. With student care being less manpower-intensive than childcare, the operating cost is, of course, much lower. The fees for student care without subsidy are similar to, if not lower than, childcare fees payable after subsidy.

Children enrolled in VWO centres may apply for fee assistance if the parents' combined income is less than $2,500. The fee assistance offsets up to 75% of the fees, with a cap of $150. We will seriously consider Mdm Halimah's suggestion to extend the fee assistance scheme to commercial centres as well. We will have to study this carefully but, meanwhile, families may also apply for further assistance from the CDCs and VWOs.

Sir, I think I have addressed most of the concerns.

     Family Values

Mdm Cynthia Phua: Our Government hopes to enable Singaporeans to make informed life choices and support the

Column: 2012

family in its roles and functions. The four key thrusts are:


(1) Imbue Singaporeans with pro-family values and encourage family formation and bonding;

(2) Equip families with knowledge and skills to create and manage quality family life;

(3) Create a pro-family environment with strong community support for families; and

(4) Encourage women's participation and contribution to family and community.

My main concerns in this area are the parent educationalist and the community's effort on the thrustof instilling family values on the young;secondly, the limited time our children spend with their parents and grandparents for the informal teaching of family and moral values. I always believe that whatever values we want to instill in our young, we must start when they are young. Childcare and student care are important support facilities for the parents to bring up their children when the parents are working. Their children spend at least five to about 10 hours in these centres, and these facilities are under the supervision of MCDS which licenses them. The standard and quality of these centres also vary.

Can the Minister consider putting in moral education as a compulsory programme for these centres? Our children read widely, and most of the books that these centres have provided are mainly knowledge-acquiring books. Can the Minister recommend and encourage these centres to provide some standard moral education materials? Children need to be exposed to moral value teaching constantly, as this role is traditionally done by their parents and grandparents. However, at these centres,

Column: 2013

an added dosage would be good for the children. Most parents, after work, have limited time with their children, and such values are also difficult to be taught and must relate to values through life experiences.

In addition, I would also like to urge the Pro-Family Committee to encourage grassroots leaders, organisations, cultural and family support agencies, such as the Family Service Centres and neighbourhood links, to put more emphasis in the thrust of promoting family values in their activities.

     Parenting

Dr Lily Neo: Sir, there is a need for a change of the attitude of parenting towards "Happy Parenting". There had been too many negative reports and negative emphasis of parenthood. We need to start an aggressive campaign to correct this negative mindset. The emphasis on such campaigning should be on the joy that family brings.


There is a general tendency for the younger people in our workforce to put off courtship, marriage and childbearing to very much later on in their lives. Parents and young people should abandon the mindset that students should not court until they have graduated and are established in their careers because, by then, it becomes increasingly difficult to interact and to start courting. Young people would be well advised to be responsible adults who are accountable in their relationship, responsible towards others, and sensible in pursuing studies simultaneously with a relationship without jeopardising one or the other.

In Singapore, women assume the main responsibility of housework and childcare, regardless of whether they are employed. Working women are often stressed from

Column: 2014

the multiple responsibilities. Research into marital satisfaction among Singaporean women showed a direct correlation between stress levels in women and the amount of help they get at home. Traditionally, the father had been the sole breadwinner and the distant disciplinarian while the mother had been the nurturer and homemaker. In the present dual-income family, there should be a shift away from this perception of the roles of fathers and mothers. Parenting and homemaker tasks should be shared between spouses. More effort should be spent in this area, perhaps through campaigning and promoting a change in the stereo mindset of many men regarding parenting and household responsibility, and to be equal partners in raising families.

     Value of Children

Assoc. Prof. Ngiam Tee Liang: Sir, I am concerned about some of the feedback given by members of the public recently when asked to comment on the new proposed measures to boost our fertility rate.
